questions.text: A Patient, 52 years old with end-stage renal disease is going for hemodialysis. This hemodialysis is between 9 and 12 hours and it is to be done every week usually divided into 3 equal sessions. What is the most common complication expected to be developed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypotension Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus Some of the risk factors include excess ultrafiltration with inadequate compensatory vascular filling, autonomic responses, or osmolar shift. Hypotension during dialysis can be frequently prevented by careful evaluation of the dry weight and by ultrafiltration modelling Excessive rapid fluid removal greater than 13 millilitres per kg per hour should be avoided Additional manoeuvres to prevent intra-dialytic hypotension include the performance of sequential ultrafiltration followed by dialysis The management of hypotension during dialysis consists of discontinuing ultrafiltration, administration of 100 to 250 ml of isotonic saline or 10 ml of 23% saturated hypertonic saline, or administration of salt-poor albumin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Anaphylactoid reaction Anaphylactoid reactions to the dialyser, particularly on its first use, have been reported most frequently with the bio incompatible cellulosic -containing membranes However, this is not a common complication Option: C. Muscle cramps Muscle cramps following dialysis are also a common complication but not as common as hypotension The aetiology of dialysis-associated cramps remains obscure Reducing volume removal during dialysis, ultrafiltration profiling, and the use of sodium modelling have been used to reduce the occurrence of muscle cramps

Extraedge:

Common complications during Hemodialysis IntraDialytic Hypotension Intradialytic Hypertension Chest pain/dyspnea Dialyser reactions Cramps Syncope Seizures Headache Nausea vomiting Fever Non Functioning Acesses

questions.text: There are 4 patients in the intensive care unit with end-stage renal disease. Patient 1 is having metabolic acidosis. Patient 2 is having a pleural effusion. Patient 3 is having pericarditis. Patient 4 is having hyperkalemia. Hemodialysis is to be done for one of these patients. For which of them hemodialysis is an absolute indication?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pericarditis Pericarditis Clear indications for initiation of renal replacement therapy for patients with CKD include Uremic pericarditis, encephalopathy, Intractable muscle cramping, anorexia, nausea not attributable to reversible causes such as peptic ulcer disease, evidence of malnutrition, and fluid and electrolyte abnormalities, principally hyperkalemia or ecfv overload, that are refractory to other measures. In a patient with end-stage renal disease aka chronic kidney disease, the absolute indication of hemodialysis is pericarditis This is because the pericarditis can cause haemorrhage at any time in the pericardial sac this will result in cardiac tamponade and will cause obstructive shock This is an emergency and critical situation Hence hemodialysis is an absolute indication of pericarditis in CKD

Highyeild:

Absolute indications for Hemodialysis Uremic Pericarditis/Pleuritis Uremic Encephalopathy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Metabolic acidosis metabolic acidosis can be managed with the help of sodium bicarbonate Option: B. Pleural effusion Pleural effusion is also an emergency condition but it is not as critical as pericarditis Option: D. Hyperkalemia Hyperkalemia can be managed with potassium-binding resins and eventually increasing the dietary intake of potassium Only in emergency conditions of hyperkalemia, dialysis is required

questions.text: The patient with the following clinical presentation, was on peritoneal dialysis. He was on chronic warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation. This finding is known as -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calciphylaxis Calciphylaxis It is heralded by livedo reticularis and advances to patches of ischemic necrosis, especially on the legs, thighs, abdomen, and breasts Pathologically, there is evidence of vascular occlusion in association with extensive vascular and soft tissue calcification. Calciphylaxis is a small painful nodule on the skin It is followed by progressive skin necrosis and ulceration of the skin Treatment includes hyperbaric oxygen, intravenous thiosulfate and discontinuation of warfarin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Hyperpigmentation This is usually a yellow pigmentation found in the skin due to retention of urochrome and discolouration seen in hemochromatosis Option: C. Tumor calcinosis Tumour calcinosis is usually a painful mass that is extensively calcified This is seen in patients who is undergoing hemodialysis for many years and is Non –adherent to dietary phosphorus restriction or the use of phosphate binders Option: D. Fibrosing dermopathy It is a fatal skin condition called nephrogenic systemic fibrosis aka fibrosing dermopathy in which there is progressive subcutaneous induration, especially on the arm and leg.

Extraedge:

Studies have suggested the following risk factors for the development of calciphylaxis in end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) patients Hyperphosphatemia Medications including calcium-based binders and vitamin D analogues, nutritional vitamin D, and systemic glucocorticoids Female sex Obesity (body mass index [BMI] >30) Hypercoagulable states, such as protein C and S deficiency and antiphospholipid syndrome Hypoalbuminemia Diabetes Longer dialysis vintage Inflammatory and autoimmune conditions Recurrent skin trauma

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient is suffering from end-stage renal disease. The following drugs can't be given to the patient except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sirolimus Sirolimus is a non-nephrotoxic drug Also, it is a motor inhibitor with a long half-life It was the first motor inhibitor to be developed in solid organ transplantation that inhibits cell proliferation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Cyclosporine Cyclosporine is a nephrotoxic drug with many side effects such as hypertension, infection, hepatotoxicity etcetera Hence it is required to monitor the blood pressure, creatine and, bun, liver enzymes Option: B. Tacrolimus Tacrolimus is also a nephrotoxic drug with many side effects such as hypertension, infection, hepatotoxicity Hence it is required to monitor the blood pressure, creatine and, bun, liver enzymes Option: C. Amphotericin b Amphotericin b is a nephrotoxic drug primarily affecting the tubules by pre Renal mechanism

questions.text: The patient, 43 years old, presented with urinary albumin excretion of 30 mg per day and raised urea creatinine for more than 3 months. Which of the following is the most common cause of this rise?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetic nephropathy Diabetic nephropathy The patient has kidney damage detected with urinary albumin excretion of 30 mg per day and there is also a decrease in kidney function for greater than 3 months This means the patient is suffering from end-stage renal disease for which the new term is chronic kidney disease The most common cause of end-stage renal disease is diabetic nephropathy

Highyeild:

Leading Categories of Etiologies of CKD a ● Diabetic nephropathy ● Glomerulonephritis ● Hypertension-associated CKD (includes vascular and ischemic kidney disease and primary glomerular disease with associated hypertension) ● Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease ● Another cystic and tubulointerstitial nephropathy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hypertension Hypertension is one of the causes for end-stage renal disease aka chronic renal failure Patients with newly diagnosed CKD often have hypertension but it is not the most common cause Option: C. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease This is also one of the causes of CKD but it is not the most common cause Option: D. Alport syndrome Alport syndrome is one of the causes of chronic kidney disease but it is not the most common cause Also after transplantation the kidney will not be able to form new lesions

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient with increased urea creatinine and small-size kidneys on usg scan can have all of the following electrolyte abnormalities except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypophosphatemia Hypophosphatemia Diabetic patient with small kidney size indicates CKD In chronic kidney disease- in the case of potassium homeostasis only hyperphosphatemia is possible This is because of the retention of phosphate This retention is due to a decline in gfr leading to reduced excretion of phosphate and this retained phosphate stimulates the increased synthesis of both FGF 23 by osteocytes and PTH and stimulate the growth of parathyroid gland mass Hence chronic kidney disease will cause hyperphosphatemia and not hypophosphatemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hypocalcaemia The increase in phosphate levels will take out the calcium from the bones leading to weak bones and causing hypocalcemia Decrease the level of ionized calcium, resulting from suppression of Calcitriol, production by FGF 23 and by the failing kidney will stimulate parathyroid hormone production Option: D. Hyperkalemia Hyperkalemia is possible in chronic kidney disease mainly because of the medications that are taken in the course of the disease This medication can inhibit renal potassium excretion and lead to hyperkalemia The most important medications in this respect include ras inhibitors and spironolactone and other potassium-sparing diuretics such as amiloride

questions.text: Chronic kidney disease occurs when a disease or condition impairs kidney function, causing kidney damage to worsen over several months or years. All of the following are risk factors for chronic kidney disease EXCEPT?

options.label: D
options.text: A family history of kidney disease

questions.correct_answer: A. Large for gestational birth weight
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Large for gestational birth weight Risk factors include small for gestation birth weight , childhood obesity, hypertension , diabetes mellitus , autoimmune disease , advanced age, African ancestry, a family history of kidney disease, a previous episode of acute kidney injury, and the presence of proteinuria, abnormal urinary sediment, or structural abnormalities of the urinary tract.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C, and D: These are included as risk factors.

Extraedge:

Risk Factors Associated with Chronic Kidney Disease Age (older) Race or ethnicity (non-Caucasian) Genetics Birth weight (low) Systemic hypertension Diabetes mellitus Cardiovascular disease Albuminuria Obesity or metabolic syndrome Dyslipidemia Hyperuricemia Smoking Low socioeconomic status Nephrotoxin exposure: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), analgesics, traditional herbal use, heavy metals (such as lead)

questions.text: Regardless of the underlying etiology, CKD is slowly progressive and leads to irreversible nephron loss, end-stage renal disease and/or premature death. Factors that contribute to CKD progression include parenchymal cell loss, chronic inflammation, fibrosis and reduced regenerative capacity of the kidney. Which of the following shows the lowest risk and progression to CKD?

options.label: A
options.text: GFR 50 mL/min / 1.73 m2 and albuminuria 400 mg/g

options.label: B
options.text: GFR 50 mL/min / 1.73 m2 and albuminuria 20 mg/g

options.label: C
options.text: GFR 40 mL/min / 1.73 m2 and albuminuria 20 mg/g

options.label: D
options.text: GFR 70 mL/min / 1.73 m2 and albuminuria 400 mg/g

questions.correct_answer: B. GFR 50 mL/min / 1.73 m2 and albuminuria 20 mg/g
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GFR 50 mL/min / 1.73 m2 and albuminuria 20 mg/g Green code shows the lowest risk and progression to CKD.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Red. Option: C: Orange. Option: D: Orange. Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Gradation of colour from green to red corresponds to increasing risk and progression of CKD. GFR, glomerular filtration rate. (Reproduced with permission from Kidney Int Suppl 3:5–14, 2013.)

questions.text: Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is a test used to check how well the kidneys are working. Specifically, it estimates how much blood passes through the glomeruli each minute. A 46-year male patient has a GFR of 50 mL/min / 1.73 m2. What is the grade of CKD based on the given GFR?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

G3a Grade 3a as GFR is 50 (45-59) mL/min / 1.73 m2.

Highyeild:

GFR categories (ml/min/1.73 m²) description and range G1 Normal or high ≥90 G2 Mildly decreased 60-89 G3a Mildly to moderately decreased 45-59 G3b Moderately to severely decreased 30-44 G4 Severely decreased 15-29 G5 Kidney failure <15

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: 60-89 mL/min / 1.73 m2. Option: C: 30-44 mL/min / 1.73 m2. Option: D: 15-20 mL/min / 1.73 m2.

questions.text: A 28-year male patient presents with features of chronic kidney disease. The MRI scan is shown below. What is the most likely cause of CKD in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease MRI scan shows multiple cysts in bilateral kidneys.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, D: Not consistent with MRI findings. Leading Categories of Etiologies of CKD a ● Diabetic nephropathy ● Glomerulonephritis ● Hypertension-associated CKD (includes vascular and ischemic kidney disease and primary glomerular disease with associated hypertension) ● Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease ● Another cystic and tubulointerstitial nephropathy

questions.text: Kidney disease causes the levels of electrolytes in the body to become unbalanced, which negatively affects nerve cell function and causes the nerves to work abnormally. Peripheral neuropathy as a result of kidney disease is referred to as uremic neuropathy. Which of the following is NOT true about peripheral neuropathy in CKD?

options.label: A
options.text: Usually becomes clinically evident after the patient reaches stage 4 CKD

options.label: B
options.text: Initially, sensory nerves are involved more than motor

options.label: D
options.text: Distal parts of the extremities more than proximal

questions.correct_answer: C. Upper extremities more than lower
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Upper extremities more than lower Peripheral neuropathy usually becomes clinically evident after the patient reaches stage 4 CKD, although electrophysiologic and histologic evidence occurs earlier. Initially, sensory nerves are involved more than motor, lower extremities more than the upper, and distal parts of the extremities more than proximal. Evidence of peripheral neuropathy without another cause (e.g., diabetes mellitus or iron deficiency) is an indication for starting renal replacement therapy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, D: True about neuropathy in CKD.

questions.text: If nerve cells become damaged, the amount of dopamine in the brain is reduced, which causes muscle spasms and involuntary movements. Dopamine levels naturally fall towards the end of the day, which may explain why the symptoms of restless legs syndrome are often worse in the evening and during the night. Which is FALSE regarding restless leg syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Ill-defined sensations of sometimes debilitating discomfort in the legs

options.label: B
options.text: Discomfort in the legs and feet increased by frequent leg movement

questions.correct_answer: B. Discomfort in the legs and feet increased by frequent leg movement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Discomfort in the legs and feet increased by frequent leg movement The ‘Restless leg syndrome’ is characterized by ill-defined sensations of sometimes debilitating discomfort in the legs and feet relieved by frequent leg movement.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, C, D: True about restless leg syndrome in CKD.

questions.text: A 48 year diabetic male is on insulin for 8 year and develops CKD. How should the dose of insulin be adjusted with progressive decline in renal function?

options.label: C
options.text: No adjustment required as kidney doesn't participate in insulin removal

options.label: D
options.text: Needs adjustment but kidney doesn't participate in insulin removal

questions.correct_answer: B. May to need progressive decrement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

May to need progressive decrement Because the kidney contributes to insulin removal from the circulation, plasma levels of insulin are slightly too moderately elevated in most uremic patients, both in the fasting and postprandial states. Because of this diminished renal degradation of insulin, patients on insulin therapy may need a progressive reduction in dose as their renal function worsens.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Insulin and many anti-diabetic drugs need dose reduction in CKD. Option: C: Kidney contributes to insulin removal from circulation. Option: D: Kidney contributes to insulin removal from circulation.

questions.text: A 26 year married female with CKD comes to OPD. She needs counselling about her pregnancy outcome. Her GFR is ~40 mL/min. What advice would you give?

options.label: A
options.text: Only ~20% of pregnancies lead to live births, but pregnancy may slow the progression of kidney disease itself

options.label: B
options.text: Only ~80% of pregnancies lead to live births, but pregnancy may slow the progression of the kidney disease itself

options.label: C
options.text: Only ~20% of pregnancies lead to live births, and pregnancy may hasten the progression of the kidney disease itself

options.label: D
options.text: Only ~80% of pregnancies lead to live births, and pregnancy may hasten the progression of the kidney disease itself

questions.correct_answer: C. Only ~20% of pregnancies lead to live births, and pregnancy may hasten the progression of the kidney disease itself
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only ~20% of pregnancies lead to live births, and pregnancy may hasten the progression of the kidney disease itself When the GFR has declined to ~40 mL/min, pregnancy is associated with a high rate of spontaneous abortion , with only ~20% of pregnancies leading to live births, and pregnancy may hasten the progression of the kidney disease itself.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B: Pregnancy may hasten the progression of the kidney disease itself. Option: D: Only ~20% of pregnancies leading to live births.

questions.text: While attending rounds, you come across a patient admitted with urosepsis. Culture sensitivity shows E Coli susceptible to meropenem. The attending physician wants to start meropenem at a renal modified dose as the patients creatinine is 2.2 mg/dl. He asks you to calculate the eGFR using the CKD-EPI formula. All the following are a component of the CKD-EPI equation except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Body weight The CKD-EPI(Chronic Kidney Disease Epidemiology Collaboration) formula for estimating eGFR is as follows The CKD-EPI creatinine equation of 2012 is: GFR=141 X min(Scr/x, 1) a X max(Scr/x, 1) -1.209 X 0.993 Age X 1.018[if female] X 1.159 [if black] x = 0.7 if female x = 0.9 if male a=-0.329 if female a= -0.411 if male min = The minimum of Scr/k or 1 max = The maximum of Scr/k or 1 As seen from above formula, body weight is not a component of CKD EPI formula -The Modification of Diet in renal Disease (MDRD) equation is similar to the CKD EPI formula and these 2 equations are more accurate than cockroft gault formula.

questions.text: A 58 year old male is a known diabetic and hypertensive for the last 20 years. He has had complaints of swelling of bilateral feet and passing frothy urine for 3 months. On examination pallor+ and bilateral pitting pedal oedema up to the ankle. JVP is normal. Lab investigations show S creatinine of 3.5mg/dl , Hb-10.2g/dl and urine routine shows 3+ proteinuria. USG shows a normal-sized kidney with loss of CMD. Signs and symptoms of CKD appear when GFR falls below what level ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30ml/min/m2/1.72m2 CKD defined as the presence of kidney damage (usually detected as urinary albumin excretion of 30mg/day or more or equivalent) or decrease in kidney functions (GFR< 60ml/min/1.73m 2 ) for ≥ 3 months -Most patients with slowly progressive disease are asymptomatic until GFR falls below 30 ml/min/1.73m2. Early symptom is nocturia due to loss of concentrating ability and increased osmotic load per nephron CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE(ckd) Definition - CKD refers to the permanent loss of renal function, which culminates in signs and symptoms termed uremia. Common Causes :- Diabetic nephropathy (M/C of CRF) Hypertension Chronic glomerulonephritis Autosomal dominant Polycystic kidney disease Chronic pyelonephritis Interstitial nephritis. Alport syndrome Cockcroft-Gault equation ( Recommended Equations for estimation of GFR using serum creatinine concentration (Pcr), Age, Sex, Race and body weight.) Signs and symptoms of CRF appear when GFR goes down below 30%.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are not the correct options.

questions.text: A 65 year old female known case of CKD presented with skin changes as shown below. What is the cause for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased capillary density at the distal half of nails

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased capillary density at the distal half of nails
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased capillary density at the distal half of nails Skin changes in CRF:- Pruritus (due to uremia) Ecchymosis Hyperpigmentation (yellow hyperpigmentation due to retention of urochrome and discolouration due to hemochromatosis Nail & Half nail (also known as Lindsay Nail) occur due to Increased capillary density at the distal half of nails A fatal skin condition called nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (fibrosing dermopathy) in which progressive subcutaneous induration, especially on the arms and legs occurs It is seen in patients with CKD, most commonly on dialysis. Exposure to the magnetic resonance contrast agent, gadolinium, may precipitate this syndrome. Calciphylaxis is one type of extraskeletal calcification.It is a devastating condition seen almost exclusively in patients with advanced CKD.

questions.text: A 58 year old male,k/c/o CKD stage 5 on HD thrice a week presents with Hb of 7.5g/dl. PS shows Normocytic normochromic anemia and a Serum ferritin level of 800 mcg/l He was planned to be started on erythropoietin stimulating agents (ESA). Exogenous ESA may be associated with increased risk of all the following except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arrhythmias Increased risk of stroke in pts with type 2 diabetes , an There has been an indication that the use of ESA in CKD may be associated with an I ncrease in thromboembolic events

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, C and D. Faster progression of renal decline . Current practice is to target a hemoglobin concentration of 10-11.5g/dl

Extraedge:

We administer ESAs to most patients with CKD who have hemoglobin (Hb) <10 g/dL, providing the transferrin saturation (TSAT) is >20 per cent and ferritin >200 ng/mL.

questions.text: A 48 year old male presented with excessive fatigue, pedal edema and passing frothy urine. The urine routine showed 3+ proteinuria. BUN-45 mg/dl and serum creatinine 5.2mg/dl. However, USG showed normal-sized kidneys. In which of the following conditions is CKD with enlarged kidney size?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes In CKD, both the kidneys are small and contracted (< 8 cm length is taken as a contracted kidney). B/L contracted kidney is the surest sign of CKD. But there are a few exceptions where patients may have CRF but with normal or enlarged kidney size.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A , B and C are associated with an enlarged kidney.

questions.text: In hemodialysis, a machine filters wastes, salts and fluid from your blood when your kidneys are no longer healthy enough to do this work adequately. Hemodialysis is one way to treat advanced kidney failure and can help you carry on an active life despite failing kidneys. Which of the following is the commonest complication of hemodialysis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypotension Hemodialysis (HD):- Blood flows opposite to the dialysis fluid, and substances are exchanged down a concentration gradient across a semipermeable membrane, between the two compartments. Indications of hemodialysis:- ARF Toxins (Methanol poisoning) Drugs (Salicylate poisoning) CRF patients awaiting renal transplantation Dialysis is not effective in following poisonings:- Digoxin Barbiturate Kerosene Copper sulphate Organophosphorus poisoning

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Features which develop after the start of Hemodialysis (HD):- Hypotension (most common) Option: B. Hepatitis Adynamic osteomalacia Anaphylactoid reactions to dialyzer muscle cramps Hypocomplementemia Disequilibrium syndrome refers to CNS symptoms ranging from nausea to seizures related to volume depletion and osmolar shifts, usually occurring with the initiation of treatment. Option: D. Dialysis Dementia occurs after a few years of dialysis. It is due to aluminium intoxication Syndrome of speech dysfunction, dyspraxia, seizures and myoclonus.

questions.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is an inherited condition that causes small fluid-filled sacs called cysts to develop in the kidneys. All of the following are included as risk factors of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in ADPKD EXCEPT ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Small kidney size The progression of ADPKD has striking inter- and intrafamilial variability. The disease can present as early as in utero, but end-stage renal disease (ESRD) typically occurs in late middle age. Risk factors include early diagnosis of ADPKD, hypertension, gross hematuria, multiple pregnancies, and large kidney size.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, C: Well known risk factors.
